head.name: TAN keywords for types of groups
head.desc: Definitive list of key terms used for types of groups.

item.name: div types
item.desc: The group contains items that define groups of division types

item.name: attr n
attribute n
tan lm
item.desc: The group contains items that define groups relevant only in the context of @n

item.name: verb types
item.desc: The group contains items that define groups relevant to verbs

item.name: does not start new line
no new line start
inline start
not nls
not(^\n)
item.desc: Text divisions that typically do not begin on a new line

item.name: no new line end
does not end new line
inline end
not nle
not(\n$)
item.desc: Text divisions whose termination does not force the next text division to start a new line

item.name: start new line
new line start
nls
^\n
item.desc: Text divisions that typically begin on a new line

item.name: new line end
end new line
nle
\n$
item.desc: Text divisions whose termination forces the next text division to start a new line

item.name: start extra leading
extra leading start
space above
item.desc: Text divisions that typically begin with extra leading (a horizontal line of white space)

item.name: end extra leading
extra leading end
space below
item.desc: Text divisions that typically end with extra leading (a horizontal line of white space)

item.name: start new column
new column start
ncs
item.desc: Text divisions that typically begin on a new column

item.name: new column end
end new column
nce
item.desc: Text divisions whose termination forces the next text division to start a new column

item.name: start new page
new page start
nps
item.desc: Text divisions that typically begin on a new page

item.name: new page end
end new page
npe
item.desc: Text divisions whose termination forces the next text division to start a new page

item.name: logical
conceptual
item.desc: Text division is based on logical units that do not depend upon scripta for their meaning, e.g., sentence, paragraph. Contrasts with physical, scriptum-based divisions.

item.name: scriptum
scriptum based
object
physical
material
item.desc: Text division is based on a physical feature in the scriptum, e.g., page, column, line. Contrasts with logical divisions.

item.name: status
base
item.desc: @n is the result of applying tan:string-base($i), where $i is the value of the token chosen.

item.name: root
item.desc: @n is the root of the token chosen

item.name: start1
a
item.desc: @n is the first letter of the token chosen

item.name: start2
ab
item.desc: @n is the first two letters of the token chosen

item.name: start3
abc
item.desc: @n is the first three letters of the token chosen

item.name: end1
z
item.desc: @n is the last letter of the token chosen

item.name: end2
yz
item.desc: @n is the last two letters of the token chosen

item.name: end3
xyz
item.desc: @n is the last three letters of the token chosen

item.name: textual artefact subject
item.desc: Verbs whose subjects are entire textual artefacts (scripta, works, versions, sources).

item.name: textual artefact object
item.desc: verbs whose objects are entire textual artefacts (scripta, works, versions, sources).

item.name: textual passage subject
item.desc: Verbs whose subjects are specific passages of textual artefacts (scripta, works, versions, sources).

item.name: textual passage object
item.desc: verbs whose objects are specific passages of textual artefacts (scripta, works, versions, sources).

item.name: textual artefact or passage subject
item.desc: Verbs whose subjects are textual artefacts or specific passages of textual artefacts (scripta, works, versions, sources).

item.name: textual artefact or passage object
item.desc: Verbs whose objects are textual artefacts or specific passages of textual artefacts (scripta, works, versions, sources).

item.name: textual entity subject
item.desc: verbs whose subjects are creators of texts (persons, organizations) or bearers of texts (scripta, works, versions, sources)

item.name: textual entity object
item.desc: verbs whose objects are creators of texts (persons, organizations) or bearers of texts (scripta, works, versions, sources)

item.name: textual subject
item.desc: verbs whose subjects are textual passages or textual entities

item.name: textual object
item.desc: verbs whose objects are textual passages or textual entities

item.name: claim object
item.desc: verbs whose objects are claims

item.name: zero objects
item.desc: verbs that do not allow objects

item.name: one object
item.desc: verbs that require only one object

item.name: one or more objects
item.desc: verbs that must take one or more objects

item.name: zero loci
item.desc: verbs that do not allow loci

item.name: one locus
item.desc: verbs that require only one locus

item.name: one or more loci
item.desc: verbs that must take one or more loci

item.name: near verbatim
item.desc: verbs where each pair of subject and object textual passages have an agreement of 70% or greater.

If subject and object are in the same language, the quantity is measured by agreement after normalization, ignoring accentuation, capitalization, punctuation, and word spaces. If they are in different languages, the quantity is measured by the number of words in one source that correspond to words in the other.

item.name: similar
item.desc: verbs where each pair of subject and object textual passages have an agreement of 40% to 70%
See description for verbatim.

item.name: somewhat similar
item.desc: verbs where each pair of subject and object textual passages have an agreement of 5% to 40%
See description for verbatim.

item.name: cf
item.desc: verbs that indicate a comparison between subject and object

item.name: symmetry
item.desc: verbs that permit symmetrical inferences
If X [verb] Y then Y [verb] X.

item.name: transitivity
item.desc: verbs that permit transitive inferences
If X [verb] Y and Y [verb] Z then X [verb] Z.

item.name: subject postdates object
item.desc: verbs whose subjects must postdate objects
If a textual passage is said to quote from another, then the former must postdate the latter.
